Patch Set 12:

(1 comment)

Hello; The comments on [fw_update: Add encode req & decode resp for query_downtream_identifiers](https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/libpldm/+/70729) also apply to this patch. Please identify the corresponding issues and fix.
Done, please review, thanks.
Hi, thanks for reviewing, all the suggestions sounds good to me, I've modifed the code and marked resolved, please let me know if there is any additional suggestion.
Please drop `__attribute__((packed))`, and provide macros exposing the size of relevant wire-format message (sub)structures.
Done
Can we please swap the order of these two (and fix the doxygen comment)?
Done
Please implement this using the `msgbuf` APIs.
Done, refactored to `msgbuf` and modified related unit test cases.

Hi, I've have some comments inline. Broadly, one of the purposes of the `msgbuf` APIs is to deal with the endian conversions for you, in addition to being spatially memory-safe and avoiding various forms of undefined behaviour (mainly around issues of alignment). Some of the comments are on that theme.
I expect you should rather extract the values straight into the members of `resp_data`.
Done

Done, thanks for reminding, I would like to check something:

Before the commit to split `pldm_msgbuf_extract` and `pldm_msgbuf_extract_p`, `pldm_msgbuf_extract` accepts a pointer, if I take the address of the struct member, such as `&resp_data->completion_code`, it might get the wrong address with some padded struct, am I correct? I remember that I've encountered such error before.
Extract this directly into `resp_data->downstream_device_update_supported`.
Done
I'd prefer we invert this condition and do an early return rather than have an `else` branch.
Done
`pldm_msgbuf_extract(buf, resp_data->number_of_downstream_devices)`.
Done
This is unnecessary (and incorrect). The `msgbuf` API already does the endianness conversion for you.
Done
See comments above.
Done

This must at least be `return pldm_msgbuf_destroy(buf);`. Preferably `return pldm_msgbuf_destroy_consumed(buf);`. The design of the `msgbuf` APIs is such that most of the time the error handling can be punted to the caller, and the `pldm_msgbuf_destroy*()` functions are how we implement this signalling.
Done
Please don't submit commented out code.
Oops, that's a missed part, sorry for that.
Hello, the only remaining comments I have are regarding some whitespace in the comments. I think the code looks good now. Thanks for iterating on it.

Bit of a nit, but can we un-indent this?

I appreciate the use of the markdown-style quote though 😊
Done, thank you😇
Actually, are we going to use these in practice? I think we can omit them? I just prefer to not add to the library API unless we really need to.
Right, yes, I think it's best if we don't require unnecessary parameters. Can we please use your pseudo code above?
Sure, done and removed the unneeded marco.
Same here (remove indendation). Maybe also turn the explanation into a list?
Done, not sure if the list-style is good to you.
That'll do for now, thanks.
Done
Looking good!
Thanks for the suggestion.🙂
Hi, I have a preference that we go with the pseudo code option and drop the unnecessary length macros.
Hello, we're down to a few straight-forward comments inline. Thanks for iterating on the patch!

Actually, on further thought this should go in `base.h` instead, as the base spec (DSP0240) is where the `ERROR_UNSUPPORTED_PLDM_CMD` error code is defined. Moving this now before we merge the patch means that we don't have people having to swap `#include`s around later on.
Done
Do we need this any more?
This was revised by clang-tidy, the error disappeared after I moved `ERROR_UNSUPPORTED_PLDM_CMD` to base.h. It should be good now, thanks.
This should be `out`, not `in,out`.
Done
So close!
Very much a nitpick, but can you indent this properly? There should be one space at the start of the line so the stars line up.
Done
